Solution.

(iii)   ⟹  \implies⟹ (i):

Let x0∈Xx_0 \in Xx0​∈X and ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. Consider BY(f(x0),ε)B_Y\p{f\p{x_0}, \varepsilon}BY​(f(x0​),ε), which is an open set (by the long proposition). Thus, by assumption, f−1(BY(f(x0),ε))f^{-1}\p{B_Y\p{f\p{x_0}, \varepsilon}}f−1(BY​(f(x0​),ε)) is also open and contains x0x_0x0​ by construction. Thus, (by the long proposition again, x0x_0x0​ is an interior point, so) there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that BX(x0,δ)⊆f−1(BY(f(x0),ε))B_X\p{x_0, \delta} \subseteq f^{-1}\p{B_Y\p{f\p{x_0}, \varepsilon}}BX​(x0​,δ)⊆f−1(BY​(f(x0​),ε)). In other words,

dX(x,x0)<δ  ⟹  x∈BX(x0,δ)  ⟹  x∈f−1(BY(f(x0),ε))  ⟹  f(x)∈BY(f(x0),ε)  ⟹  dY(f(x),f(x0))<ε,\begin{aligned} d_X\p{x, x_0} < \delta &\implies x \in B_X\p{x_0, \delta} \\ &\implies x \in f^{-1}\p{B_Y\p{f\p{x_0}, \varepsilon}} \\ &\implies f\p{x} \in B_Y\p{f\p{x_0}, \varepsilon} \\ &\implies d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f\p{x_0}} < \varepsilon, \end{aligned}dX​(x,x0​)<δ​⟹x∈BX​(x0​,δ)⟹x∈f−1(BY​(f(x0​),ε))⟹f(x)∈BY​(f(x0​),ε)⟹dY​(f(x),f(x0​))<ε,​

so fff is continuous at x0x_0x0​ because ε\varepsilonε was arbitrary. Since x0x_0x0​ was also arbitrary, this shows that fff is continuous.

(iii)   ⟺  \iff⟺ (iv):

Given any subset E⊆YE \subseteq YE⊆Y, we have

x∈f−1(Y∖E)  ⟺  f(x)∈Y∖E  ⟺  f(x)∉E  ⟺  x∉f−1(E)  ⟺  x∈X∖f−1(E).\begin{aligned} x \in f^{-1}\p{Y \setminus E} &\iff f\p{x} \in Y \setminus E \\ &\iff f\p{x} \notin E \\ &\iff x \notin f^{-1}\p{E} \\ &\iff x \in X \setminus f^{-1}\p{E}. \end{aligned}x∈f−1(Y∖E)​⟺f(x)∈Y∖E⟺f(x)∈/E⟺x∈/f−1(E)⟺x∈X∖f−1(E).​

In other words,

f−1(Y∖E)=X∖f−1(E).(∗)f^{-1}\p{Y \setminus E} = X \setminus f^{-1}\p{E}. \tag{$*$}f−1(Y∖E)=X∖f−1(E).(∗)

If (iii) holds, then given a closed set F⊆YF \subseteq YF⊆Y, (the long proposition implies) its complement Y∖FY \setminus FY∖F is open, so by (iii), f−1(Y∖F)f^{-1}\p{Y \setminus F}f−1(Y∖F) is open and by (∗*∗), its complement is f−1(F)f^{-1}\p{F}f−1(F) and must be closed.

Similarly, if (iv) holds, then given an open V⊆YV \subseteq YV⊆Y, its complement Y∖VY \setminus VY∖V is closed. Using (iv), f−1(Y∖V)f^{-1}\p{Y \setminus V}f−1(Y∖V) is closed and using (∗*∗) again, we see f−1(V)f^{-1}\p{V}f−1(V) must be open.

Common Mistakes

The most common mistakes were giving examples since the choice of XXX and YYY can make or break your example. For example, if you define f ⁣:R→{0}\func{f}{\R}{\set{0}}f:R→{0} by f(x)=0f\p{x} = 0f(x)=0, then while it's true that f(R)={0}f\p{\R} = \set{0}f(R)={0} still, the problem is that in the (discrete) metric space {0}\set{0}{0}, the singleton {0}\set{0}{0} is open.

Similarly, I saw some students use f ⁣:R→[0,∞)\func{f}{\R}{\pco{0, \infty}}f:R→[0,∞), f(x)=x2f\p{x} = x^2f(x)=x2, and U=(−1,1)U = \p{-1, 1}U=(−1,1). The issue here is that [0,∞)\pco{0, \infty}[0,∞) has different open sets from R\RR itself. Indeed, f(U)=(0,1]f\p{U} = \poc{0, 1}f(U)=(0,1] which is not open in R\RR, but is relatively open in [0,∞)\pco{0, \infty}[0,∞) since

[0,1)=(−1,1)∩[0,∞).\pco{0, 1} = \p{-1, 1} \cap \pco{0, \infty}.[0,1)=(−1,1)∩[0,∞).
